  • Grass or weeds tightly held in hands (cadaveric Spasm): Surest sign
  • Drowning Froth Over Mouth and Nose and in air passages: Second best sign
  • Emphysema Aquosum (overinflated lungs)
  • Presence of sand / mud etc. in respiratory passages especially in terminal part
  • Diatom test
  • Presence of water especially if mixed with mud / sand etc. in Stomach or intestines
  • Paltauff Haemorrhage (Subpleural Haemorrhage)
  • Gettler’s test

 

Signs of Immersion

 

  • Washerwoman’s hand / feet
  • Cutis anserina=goose skin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water in stomach: This suggests that the person was alive when entering the water and swallowed water, indicating antemortem drowning.

 

Option C. White leathery foam around mouth and nostrils: This foam, often referred to as "drowning froth," is a strong indicator of antemortem drowning as it forms when water mixes with air and mucus in the airways.

 

Option D. Positive diatom test: The presence of diatoms in the organs indicates that the person inhaled water while still alive, allowing these microscopic algae to enter the bloodstream and be deposited in various tissues, thus confirming antemortem drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Washerwoman's hands and feet indicate immersion in water but do not specify drowning as the cause of death, unlike other indicators such as water in the stomach, white leathery foam, and a positive diatom test, which strongly suggest antemortem drowning.

questions.text: In 18th century British East India company used to transport which substance of abuse to China: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Opium

 

Opium is derived from the poppy plant and has been used both medicinally and recreationally. In the 18th and 19th centuries, the British East India Company exported vast quantities of opium to China, leading to widespread addiction and the Opium Wars, which had significant geopolitical consequences.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marijuana: A psychoactive drug from the Cannabis plant, used both recreationally and medicinally around the world.

 

Option C. Cocaine: Derived from the coca plant, cocaine is a powerful stimulant used primarily as a recreational drug.

 

Option D. Magic Mushrooms: Refer to various types of mushrooms that contain psilocybin, a psychoactive compound. These have been used for centuries for their hallucinogenic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In 18th century British East India company used to transport opium to China.

questions.text: Declaration of Oslo is for? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Therapeutic abortion

 

The Declaration of Oslo was adopted by the World Medical Association (WMA) to address the ethical considerations involved in therapeutic abortion. Therapeutic abortion refers to the termination of pregnancy performed to save the life of the pregnant woman, preserve her physical or mental health, or in cases of severe fetal abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Torture: The Declaration of Tokyo is the relevant document that deals with the ethical guidelines for doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment.

 

Option C. Hunger: The Declaration of Malta on Hunger Strikes provides ethical guidelines for physicians concerning the treatment of hunger strikers. This declaration emphasizes the importance of respecting the autonomy of individuals who engage in hunger strikes.

 

Option D. Ethical aspects of medical research: The Declaration of Helsinki is the key document that outlines ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects. It emphasizes the necessity of informed consent, the welfare of research participants, and the importance of conducting research with scientific integrity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Declaration of Oslo specifically addresses the ethical considerations involved in therapeutic abortion, distinguishing it from other declarations that focus on different ethical issues in medical practice

questions.text: Amongst the poisons given below, which poison can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arsenic

 

Arsenic gets fixed to the bones and gets released from it very slowly over a period of time and thus can be detected in the bones for several years after death.

 

Toxicokinetic of Arsenic:

 

  1. Because of short half-life of arsenic in the blood, arsenic is rapidly cleared from the blood. Hence it is less reliable to detect arsenic poisoning.
  2. After clearing from blood, arsenic gets deposited in almost all the tissues where it is found for prolonged period. However, arsenic does not cross blood brain barrier.
  3. Highest concentration is found in liver (followed by kidney)
  4. Urine becomes positive within 6 hours of poisoning and may continue to be positive for about 2-3 weeks. Urine is better than blood to detect arsenic poisoning.
  5. Arsenic also gets deposited in hair, nails, skin and bones where it remains for a much more prolonged time (even for years) after exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbon monoxide: Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin in the blood but does not leave detectable residues in skeletal remains.

 

Option C. Hydrogen sulphide: Hydrogen sulphide is a gas that affects soft tissues and is not detected in skeletal remains.

 

Option D. Phosphorus: Phosphorus can affect soft tissues but is not typically detected in bones long after death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arsenic can be found in skeletal remains for several years after death due to its strong binding to the bone matrix and slow release over time.

choices.text: Hymen does not rupture because opening is too small to allow penis to enter
The hymen does not rupture because Hymen is situated deep inside

questions.text: If a young female child is raped, the hymen is usually: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both a and b

 

Rape on Children:

 

In rape of a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because of two reasons:

 

  • Vaginal opening is very small, hence penetration very difficult. Usually, the penis is placed either within the vulva or between the thighs. And as such, only redness and tenderness of vulva may be caused.
  • Hymen is deeply situated, hence even if some penetration occurred, it is not ruptured.

 

Also, in a child, there may be no signs or very few signs of general violence since the child has no idea of the act and is also unable to offer resistance.

 

However, in rare cases of great violence, the penis may be forcibly introduced, causing rupture of the vaginal vault, Hymen and associated visceral injuries. In this case the injuries will be more severe than adults and such injuries might result in death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of rape involving a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because the vaginal opening is very small, making penetration difficult, and the hymen is situated deeply. Additionally, children may not show signs of general violence due to their inability to resist, though severe injuries can occur in cases of great violence.

questions.text: Match the following in relation to fingerprint changes: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-e, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a, 5-d

 

The changes in fingerprints can be associated with various medical conditions and external factors:

 

  1. Incomplete atrophy of ridges - E. Dermatitis:
    • Dermatitis can cause inflammation and swelling, leading to incomplete atrophy of the fingerprint ridges.
  2. Loss of pattern with ridge atrophy - C. Celiac disease:
    • Celiac disease can cause skin changes and atrophy of the fingerprint ridges, leading to the loss of pattern.
  3. Altered ridges - B. Scleroderma:
    • Scleroderma causes hardening and tightening of the skin, which can alter the fingerprint ridges.
  4. Permanent loss of fingerprints - A. Radiation:
    • Exposure to radiation can cause permanent damage to the skin, leading to the permanent loss of fingerprints.
  5. Distance between ridges is changed but pattern is retained - D. Acromegaly:
    • In acromegaly, there is an increase in the growth of bones and tissues, which can change the distance between fingerprint ridges while retaining the overall pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a gunshot case, blackening is noted surrounding a firearm entry wound. Blackening occurs mainly due to: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D. Black smoke particles

 

Blackening around the entry wound is primarily due to the deposition of smoke and soot produced from the burning propellant (gunpowder). This is most notable at close range and creates a dark mark surrounding the entry site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heat Fire Effect : This involves the heat generated by the discharge of a firearm. It can cause singeing of the hair and possibly burning of the skin around the wound, but it does not usually cause blackening.

 

Option B. Muzzle of Firearm Weapon : This refers to the end of the gun barrel. While the muzzle is close to the skin, it may deposit soot and cause burns, but it is not itself a cause of blackening. It's more about proximity effects.

 

Option C. Unburnt Gunpowder Particles : When a gun is fired, unburnt particles of gunpowder can exit the muzzle along with the bullet. These particles can cause stippling or tattooing around the wound, which is not the same as blackening but related to small abrasions on the skin.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The presence of blackening, soot, and unburnt gunpowder at a gunshot entry wound provides crucial information about the distance and angle of the shot.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in chelation of heavy metals: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oximes

 

Oximes, like pralidoxime, are specifically used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase inhibited by organophosphates and are not effective for heavy metal chelation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid): Used for chelation of heavy metals such as lead and cadmium.

 

Option B. B.A.L (British Anti-Lewisite or Dimercaprol): Used for chelation of heavy metals such as lead, arsenic, and mercury.

 

Option C. Desferrioxamine: Specifically used for chelation of iron.

 

Educational Objective :

questions.text: A person working in a restaurant comes to the casualty with a huge burn on his abdomen. On examination, the injury looks like below. What is the most likely cause of the injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Moist heat

 

  • In the case scenario given above the patient has suffered from a ‘Scald injury’

  • Clinical presentation - erythema, blisters, and a line of demarcation

  • Cause of scald - application of liquid above 60°C or from steam which is moist heat.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electric burn: Electric burns typically have entry and exit points and are caused by electrical currents passing through the body, which is not seen in the image.

 

Option B. Chemical burn: Chemical burns result from exposure to corrosive substances and may have different patterns and additional signs such as discoloration or tissue damage beyond just blisters and erythema.

 

Option C. Dry heat: Burns caused by dry heat, such as flames or hot objects, usually present with charring or a different burn pattern compared to scald injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely cause of the burn injury shown in the image is moist heat, specifically a scald injury caused by hot liquids or steam.

 

TYPES of SCALD INJURIES

 

  • Immersion burns: Due to immersion in hot liquid, usually water.

  • Accidental Splash burns

  • Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.

questions.text: During fetal autopsy, what is the order of examination to differentiate between live and stillbirth? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Head > Abdomen > Thorax

 

During a fetal autopsy, the abdomen is typically examined before the thorax to assess the level of the diaphragm. The position of the diaphragm can indicate whether respiration has taken place. If the diaphragm is at the level of the 4th to 5th rib, it suggests that respiration has not occurred. If it is at the level of the 6th to 7th rib, it indicates that respiration has taken place. Although there is no strict rule about the order of examining the head, it is generally preferred to examine the head first to check for any hemorrhages. The correct sequence provided in the options is Head > Abdomen > Thorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thorax > Abdomen > Thorax: Incorrect. This option repeats the thorax examination and does not include the head, which is important for checking for hemorrhages.

 

Option B. Thorax > Head > Abdomen: Incorrect. The abdomen should be examined before the thorax to check the diaphragm level, which is crucial for determining whether respiration has occurred.

 

Option D. Head > Thorax > Abdomen: Incorrect. This option does not follow the necessary sequence where the abdomen should be examined before the thorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a fetal autopsy, the correct sequence of examination is Head > Abdomen > Thorax, with the abdomen being opened before the thorax to check the diaphragm level for respiration evidence

questions.text: Identify the rules used as tests of insanity? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both A and B

 

  • Durham's rule and Curren's rule are used in cases as tests for insanity.

  • The Durham's rule states, “an accused is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act was the product of mental disease or mental defect”.

  • The Curren's rule states that “an accused person will not be criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of law, as a result of mental disease or defect”.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both Durham's rule and Curren's rule are significant tests used to determine criminal responsibility in cases where the defendant's mental state is in question.

questions.text: What is the cause of tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Unburnt particles  

 

  • Tattooing is a term used to describe the punctate abrasions observed when skin comes into contact with partially burned or unburned grains of gunpowder.
  • They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing
  • They are seen in near (30-50cm) to mid-range of shooting

 

Firearm injuries:

 

 

Blackening – due to deposit of smoke

 

 

 

Grease collar - due to the deposition of the lubricant of the bullet in the tissues

 

Burn injuries - occur due to flame released during the firing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Smoke: Causes blackening, not tattooing.

 

Option C. Impact: Refers to the force of the bullet causing tissue damage but does not explain tattooing.

 

Option D. Muzzle impression: Occurs when the muzzle of the firearm makes contact with the skin, leaving an impression, but does not cause tattooing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is caused by unburnt particles of gunpowder embedding into the skin.

choices.text: Supposititious child

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins belonging to two different fathers. This case would be best described as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superfecundation

 

  • Similarities between Superfecundation and superfetation:
    • In both there is fertilization of 2 ova from 2 separate acts of coitus 
    • So twin pregnancy in both
    • Fathers can be different for the two babies in both Superfecundation and superfetation
  • Differences between Superfecundation and superfetation:
    • In Superfecundation the two acts of coitus occurred in same menstrual cycle, whereas in superfetation in two different cycles.
    • Hence, in Superfecundation both fetuses have similar development, and born at same time, whereas, in superfetation, the first fetus is more developed, and also, they may not be born at same time.

 

In the question, it is mentioned that “woman gave birth to twins”, which implies that both babies were born at same time. Hence superfecundation is a better choice than superfetation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfetation: Fertilization of a second ovum during a different menstrual cycle while a pregnancy is already ongoing. The first fetus is more developed than the second, and they may not be born at the same time.

 

Option C. Supposititious children are fraudulent offspring. These arose when an heir was required and so a suitable baby might be procured and passed off as genuine.

 

Option D. Atavism: A modification of a biological structure whereby an ancestral genetic trait reappears after having been lost through evolutionary change in previous generations. E.g. tail in humans

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two ova from separate acts of coitus within the same menstrual cycle, resulting in the birth of twins that can have different fathers and are born at the same time.

questions.text: A young male had a road traffic accident and was brought to emergency with stable vitals. Which wound is not expected:(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chop wound

 

In the context of a road traffic accident, different types of wounds can be expected depending on the nature of the injury.

 

Chop Wound typically caused by a heavy, sharp tool like an axe or a machete. These are not typically seen in road traffic accidents unless there is a very specific scenario involving such an implement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple Bruises: These are common in road traffic accidents due to blunt force trauma where the body strikes objects like the steering wheel, dashboard, or gets jostled against seat belts.

 

Option C. Graze Abrasion: Often occurs when the skin slides across a rough surface, such as in motorcycle accidents when the rider is dragged along the pavement.

 

Option D. Laceration: These are irregular tears in the skin commonly caused by blunt trauma, which is typical in road traffic accidents when sharp or rough metal edges and glass are involved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chop wounds are unusual in road traffic accidents .

choices.text: Tell sequence of events in detail after the bite

questions.text: The WHO-created slogan 'Perform Correctly,' regarding initial snake bite assistance, includes everything listed below except for which one? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Incisions

 

Do not interfere with the snake bite wound (incisions, suction, rubbing, tattooing, vigorous cleaning, massage, application of herbs or chemicals, cryotherapy, cautery) as this may introduce infection, increase absorption of the venom and increase local bleeding.

 

First Aid treatment outside the hospital setting has very limited role in snake bite management. The first aid treatment can be divided in three categories:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Reassurance: Many snake bites are caused by non-venomous snakes. And even after most venomous snake bites, the patient can be saved the risk of death is not immediate. If the patient gets panicked his heart rate would increase which in term would spread the venom rapidly.

 

Option B) Tell sequence of events in detail after the bite: Detailed history will be helpful to know the type of snake Detailed history in snakebite is essential to delineate treatment options moving forward. Information to obtain includes the timing and location of bite, the onset of any symptoms, and any first aid administered in field. Take a past medical history with detail to which medications they are on, especially anti-platelet / anti-coagulant medications, and any allergies that would prohibit from receiving antivenom.

 

Option C) Go to hospital: Main treatment of snake bite can be given in hospital only (Anti-snake venom, airway maintenance, fluids etc.)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Do not interfere with the snake bite wound. Always reassure the patient, immobilize the limb, and seek medical help immediately without attempting harmful interventions like making incisions or applying chemicals.

choices.text: Datura – Abrin
Opium- Atropine
Nux vomica - Strychnine
Abrus precatorius – Thebaine

questions.text: Which of these is the correct match of plant poisons and their active principles: (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nux vomica- Strychnine

 

  • Nux vomica contains Strychnine and brucine as its active principles. Strychnine is a highly toxic alkaloid used as a pesticide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura – Abrin

 

  • Datura contains Atropine, Hyoscyamine, and Scopolamine. Abrin is the toxic principle of Abrus precatorius (rosary pea).

 

Option B. Opium - Atropine

 

  • Opium contains Morphine, Codeine, and Thebaine. Atropine is the active principle of Datura.

 

Option D. Abrus precatorius – Thebaine

 

  • Abrus precatorius contains Abrin. Thebaine is an alkaloid found in Opium.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A 25-year-old young male who was a tattoo artist was brought dead to the casualty under mysterious circumstances. His girlfriend reported he had a large tattoo on his right hand, but this was not found on examination. Which structure should be examined to get more idea of the same? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymph nodes

 

The ink used for making a tattoo mark is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. Thus, if there is natural / iatrogenic tattoo removal the lymph nodes must be examined.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liver: The liver is involved in the detoxification and metabolism of substances, but it is not directly related to the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen filters blood and is involved in immune responses, but it does not play a role in the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option D. Skin: The skin is the primary site where tattoos are applied. However, in the case of a removed tattoo, the skin may not provide useful information about the former presence of the tattoo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examining the regional lymph nodes can reveal traces of tattoo ink even if the tattoo itself is no longer visible on the skin, providing useful forensic evidence.

choices.text: Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation
It is associated with a case of electrical burns

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the image given below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation

 

The above image shows postmortem change of marbling.

 

Marbling:

 

  1. Marbling is a characteristic colour change occurring in Putrefaction in which the superficial veins become visible on the skin due to staining by Hemoglobin or sulphmethhaemoglobin
  2. Mechanism of colour change in putrefaction:
    1. Direct staining by Hemoglobin (Hb): Lyses of RBCs occur in putrefaction which releases the Hb. This Hb itself stains the tissues and vessels producing a reddish brown coloration which later becomes greenish black.
    2. Staining by Sulph-meth-haemoglobin: Hydrogen sulphides gas produced by decomposing tissues combine with Hb to form sulph-meth-haemoglobin. This sulph-meth-haemoglobin stains the tissues and vessels producing a greenish black colour.
  3. This greenish black staining of superficial veins appears as prominent lines on the skin called Marbling
  4. Marbling is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of abdomen, shoulders, chest and inguinal region.
  5. Marbling starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in about 36–48 hours after death in summer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seen within 24 hours of death: While marbling starts within 24 hours, it becomes more prominent at around 36–48 hours.

 

Option C. Due to aseptic nonbacterial cause: Marbling is a result of bacterial activity and the decomposition process, not aseptic causes.

 

Option D. It is associated with a case of electrical burns: Marbling is not associated with electrical burns; it is a postmortem change due to putrefaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marbling, a postmortem change characterized by greenish-black lines on the skin, is due to the accumulation and formation of sulph-meth-hemoglobin during putrefaction.

choices.text: Examination in chief

questions.text: During the court proceedings, the defense lawyer asks a leading question, which the prosecutor appeals against. The judge grants the appeal. Leading questions are not allowed in all of the following except? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cross examination

 

In Cross examination, leading questions are allowed to challenge the witness's testimony and credibility.

 

Leading Question:

 

  • Leading questions in law are questions asked by lawyer, to a witness, with the goal of "putting words in the mouth of the witness," to achieve a desired response or result.
  • Answer to leading question can be given in “yes” or “No”
  • Example:
    • Has Ram killed shyam? It is a leading question.
    • Who has killed shyam? It is not a leading question
  • IEA related to leading questions are 141, 142 and 143 IEA (Indian Evidence Act).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Re-examination: Follow-up questioning by the party who called the witness, after cross-examination. In this leading questions are not allowed to ensure the witness's own account is clarified or points raised during cross-examination are rebutted without leading the witness.

 

Option C. Examination in Chief: The initial questioning of a witness by the party who called them. Leading questions are not permitted to ensure the witness's testimony is their own and not influenced by the questioner.

 

Option D. Dying Declaration: A statement made by a person who believes they are about to die, concerning the cause or circumstances of their death. Leading questions are not allowed to ensure the statement is voluntary and not influenced, preserving its reliability.

 

Educational Objective

 

Leading Questions are Not permitted in:

 

  1. Examination in chief
  2. Re-Examination
  3. Dying Declaration

 

Leading Questions are permitted in:

 

  1. Cross Examination
  2. Dying Deposition
  3. Hostile witness is an exception wherein the leading questions can be asked even in examination in chief

questions.text: In a village, the residents find a new groundwater source. After intake of water from this source many villagers presented with nausea, vomiting, dark bloody stools, conjunctivitis, and a burning sensation in the throat and stomach. Which poisoning do you suspect in this case? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Arsenic

 

The given clinical scenario points towards arsenic poisoning

 

Causes of arsenic poisoning: Arsenic poisoning occurs most often in major areas of agriculture and industrialization. It occurs through contaminated groundwater, air, soil or food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Potassium permanganate: Typically causes caustic injuries, including severe mucosal burns upon ingestion, but not the full range of symptoms described.

 

Option C. Thallium: Causes symptoms such as gastrointestinal distress, neurological symptoms, and hair loss, but does not match the full clinical picture described.

 

Option D. Lead: Lead poisoning causes anemia, abdominal pain, neurological symptoms, and kidney damage, but does not match the described symptoms of conjunctivitis and burning sensation in the throat and stomach.

 

Educational Objective:
